name: 1. Perceivable
content: Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive.

name: Guideline 1.1 Text Alternatives
content:
[Understanding Text Alternatives](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/text-alternatives.html‘) | [How to Meet Text Alternatives](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#text-alternatives‘)
Provide text alternatives for any non-text content so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language.

name: Success Criterion 1.1.1 Non-text Content
content:
All [non-text content](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-non-text-content‘) that is presented to the user has a [text alternative](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text-alternative‘) that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below.
Controls, Input
If non-text content is a control or accepts user input, then it has a [name](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-name‘) that describes its purpose. (Refer to [Success Criterion 4.1.2](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#name-role-value‘) for additional requirements for controls and content that accepts user input.)
Time-Based Media
If non-text content is time-based media, then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content. (Refer to [Guideline 1.2](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#time-based-media‘) for additional requirements for media.)
Test
If non-text content is a test or exercise that would be invalid if presented in [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘), then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
Sensory
If non-text content is primarily intended to create a [specific sensory experience](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-specific-sensory-experience‘), then text alternatives at least provide descriptive identification of the non-text content.
[CAPTCHA](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-captcha‘)
If the purpose of non-text content is to confirm that content is being accessed by a person rather than a computer, then text alternatives that identify and describe the purpose of the non-text content are provided, and alternative forms of CAPTCHA using output modes for different types of sensory perception are provided to accommodate different disabilities.
Decoration, Formatting, Invisible
If non-text content is [pure decoration](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pure-decoration‘), is used only for visual formatting, or is not presented to users, then it is implemented in a way that it can be ignored by [assistive technology](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-assistive-technologies‘).

name: Guideline 1.2 Time-based Media
content:
[Understanding Time-based Media](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/time-based-media.html‘) | [How to Meet Time-based Media](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#time-based-media‘)
Provide alternatives for time-based media.

name: Success Criterion 1.2.1 Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)
understanding: [Understanding Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/audio-only-and-video-only-prerecorded.html‘) | [How to Meet Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#audio-only-and-video-only-prerecorded‘)
content:
For [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [audio-only](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio-only‘) and prerecorded [video-only](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-video-only‘) media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a [media alternative for text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-media-alternative-for-text‘) and is clearly labeled as such:
Prerecorded Audio-only
An [alternative for time-based media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-alternative-for-time-based-media‘) is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded audio-only content.
Prerecorded Video-only
Either an alternative for time-based media or an audio track is provided that presents equivalent information for prerecorded video-only content.

name: Success Criterion 1.2.2 Captions (Prerecorded)
content: [Captions](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-captions‘) are provided for all [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [audio](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio‘) content in [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘), except when the media is a [media alternative for text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-media-alternative-for-text‘) and is clearly labeled as such.

name: Success Criterion 1.2.3 Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
understanding: [Understanding Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/audio-description-or-media-alternative-prerecorded.html‘) | [How to Meet Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#audio-description-or-media-alternative-prerecorded‘)
content: An [alternative for time-based media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-alternative-for-time-based-media‘) or [audio description](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio-descriptions‘) of the [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [video](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-video‘) content is provided for [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘), except when the media is a [media alternative for text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-media-alternative-for-text‘) and is clearly labeled as such.

name: Success Criterion 1.2.4 Captions (Live)
content: [Captions](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-captions‘) are provided for all [live](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-live‘) [audio](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio‘) content in [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.2.5 Audio Description (Prerecorded)
understanding: [Understanding Audio Description (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/audio-description-prerecorded.html‘) | [How to Meet Audio Description (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#audio-description-prerecorded‘)
content: [Audio description](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio-descriptions‘) is provided for all [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [video](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-video‘) content in [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.2.6 Sign Language (Prerecorded)
understanding: [Understanding Sign Language (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/sign-language-prerecorded.html‘) | [How to Meet Sign Language (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#sign-language-prerecorded‘)
content: [Sign language interpretation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-sign-language-interpretation‘) is provided for all [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [audio](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio‘) content in [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.2.7 Extended Audio Description (Prerecorded)
understanding: [Understanding Extended Audio Description (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/extended-audio-description-prerecorded.html‘) | [How to Meet Extended Audio Description (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#extended-audio-description-prerecorded‘)
content: Where pauses in foreground audio are insufficient to allow [audio descriptions](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio-descriptions‘) to convey the sense of the video, [extended audio description](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-extended-audio-description‘) is provided for all [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [video](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-video‘) content in [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.2.8 Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
understanding: [Understanding Media Alternative (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/media-alternative-prerecorded.html‘) | [How to Meet Media Alternative (Prerecorded)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#media-alternative-prerecorded‘)
content: An [alternative for time-based media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-alternative-for-time-based-media‘) is provided for all [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘) and for all prerecorded [video-only](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-video-only‘) media.

name: Success Criterion 1.2.9 Audio-only (Live)
content: An [alternative for time-based media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-alternative-for-time-based-media‘) that presents equivalent information for [live](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-live‘) [audio-only](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio-only‘) content is provided.

name: Guideline 1.3 Adaptable
content:
[Understanding Adaptable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/adaptable.html‘) | [How to Meet Adaptable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#adaptable‘)
Create content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure.

name: Success Criterion 1.3.1 Info and Relationships
understanding: [Understanding Info and Relationships](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html‘) | [How to Meet Info and Relationships](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#info-and-relationships‘)
content: Information, [structure](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-structure‘), and [relationships](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-relationships‘) conveyed through [presentation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-presentation‘) can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘) or are available in text.

name: Success Criterion 1.3.2 Meaningful Sequence
content: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a [correct reading sequence](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-correct-reading-sequence‘) can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.3.3 Sensory Characteristics
content:
Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on sensory characteristics of components such as shape, color, size, visual location, orientation, or sound.
Note
For requirements related to color, refer to [Guideline 1.4](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#distinguishable‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.3.4 Orientation
content:
Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation, such as portrait or landscape, unless a specific display orientation is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘).
Note
Examples where a particular display orientation may be essential are a bank check, a piano application, slides for a projector or television, or virtual reality content where content is not necessarily restricted to landscape or portrait display orientation.

name: Success Criterion 1.3.5 Identify Input Purpose
understanding: [Understanding Identify Input Purpose](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/identify-input-purpose.html‘) | [How to Meet Identify Input Purpose](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#identify-input-purpose‘)
content:
The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘) when:
* The input field serves a purpose identified in the [Input Purposes for user interface components section](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#input-purposes‘); and * The content is implemented using technologies with support for identifying the expected meaning for form input data.

name: Success Criterion 1.3.6 Identify Purpose
content: In content implemented using markup languages, the purpose of [user interface components](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘), icons, and [regions](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-regions‘) can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘).

name: Guideline 1.4 Distinguishable
content:
[Understanding Distinguishable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/distinguishable.html‘) | [How to Meet Distinguishable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#distinguishable‘)
Make it easier for users to see and hear content including separating foreground from background.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.1 Use of Color
understanding: [Understanding Use of Color](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/use-of-color.html‘) | [How to Meet Use of Color](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#use-of-color‘)
content:
Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element.
Note
This success criterion addresses color perception specifically. Other forms of perception are covered in [Guideline 1.3](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#adaptable‘) including programmatic access to color and other visual presentation coding.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.2 Audio Control
content:
If any audio on a web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to [pause](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pause‘) or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio volume independently from the overall system volume level.
Note
Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a users ability to use the whole page, all content on the web page (whether or not it is used to meet other success criteria) must meet this success criterion. See [Conformance Requirement 5: Non-Interference](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#cc5‘).

name: Success Criterion 1.4.3 Contrast (Minimum)
content:
The visual presentation of [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) and [images of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-images-of-text‘) has a [contrast ratio](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-contrast-ratio‘) of at least 4.5:1, except for the following:
Large Text
[Large-scale](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-large-scale‘) text and images of large-scale text have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1;
Incidental
Text or images of text that are part of an inactive [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘), that are [pure decoration](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pure-decoration‘), that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement.
Logotypes
Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no contrast requirement.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.4 Resize Text
content: Except for [captions](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-captions‘) and [images of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-images-of-text‘), [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) can be resized without [assistive technology](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-assistive-technologies‘) up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.5 Images of Text
understanding: [Understanding Images of Text](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/images-of-text.html‘) | [How to Meet Images of Text](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#images-of-text‘)
content:
If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) is used to convey information rather than [images of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-images-of-text‘) except for the following:
Customizable
The image of text can be [visually customized](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-visually-customized‘) to the users requirements;
Essential
A particular presentation of text is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) to the information being conveyed.
Note
Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are considered essential.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.6 Contrast (Enhanced)
content:
The visual presentation of [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) and [images of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-images-of-text‘) has a [contrast ratio](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-contrast-ratio‘) of at least 7:1, except for the following:
Large Text
[Large-scale](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-large-scale‘) text and images of large-scale text have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1;
Incidental
Text or images of text that are part of an inactive [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘), that are [pure decoration](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pure-decoration‘), that are not visible to anyone, or that are part of a picture that contains significant other visual content, have no contrast requirement.
Logotypes
Text that is part of a logo or brand name has no contrast requirement.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.7 Low or No Background Audio
understanding: [Understanding Low or No Background Audio](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/low-or-no-background-audio.html‘) | [How to Meet Low or No Background Audio](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#low-or-no-background-audio‘)
content:
For [prerecorded](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-prerecorded‘) [audio-only](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-audio-only‘) content that (1) contains primarily speech in the foreground, (2) is not an audio [CAPTCHA](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-captcha‘) or audio logo, and (3) is not vocalization intended to be primarily musical expression such as singing or rapping, at least one of the following is true:
No Background
The audio does not contain background sounds.
Turn Off
The background sounds can be turned off.
20 dB
The background sounds are at least 20 decibels lower than the foreground speech content, with the exception of occasional sounds that last for only one or two seconds.
Note
Per the definition of ‘decibel,‘ background sound that meets this requirement will be approximately four times quieter than the foreground speech content.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.8 Visual Presentation
content:
For the visual presentation of [blocks of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-blocks-of-text‘), a [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to achieve the following:
* Foreground and background colors can be selected by the user. * Width is no more than 80 characters or glyphs (40 if CJK). * Text is not justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins). * Line spacing (leading) is at least space-and-a-half within paragraphs, and paragraph spacing is at least 1.5 times larger than the line spacing. * Text can be resized without [assistive technology](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-assistive-technologies‘) up to 200 percent in a way that does not require the user to scroll horizontally to read a line of text [on a full-screen window](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-on-a-full-screen-window‘).
Note 1
Content is not required to use these values. The requirement is that a mechanism is available for users to change these presentation aspects. The mechanism can be provided by the browser or other user agent. Content is not required to provide the mechanism.
Note 2
Writing systems for some languages use different presentation aspects to improve readability and legibility. If a presentation aspect in this success criterion is not used in a writing system, content in that writing system does not need to use that presentation setting and can conform without it. Authors are encouraged to follow guidance for improving readability and legibility of text in their writing system.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.9 Images of Text (No Exception)
understanding: [Understanding Images of Text (No Exception)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/images-of-text-no-exception.html‘) | [How to Meet Images of Text (No Exception)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#images-of-text-no-exception‘)
content:
[Images of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-images-of-text‘) are only used for [pure decoration](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pure-decoration‘) or where a particular presentation of [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) to the information being conveyed.
Note
Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are considered essential.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.10 Reflow
content:
Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for:
* Vertical scrolling content at a width equivalent to 320 [CSS pixels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-css-pixels‘); * Horizontal scrolling content at a height equivalent to 256 [CSS pixels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-css-pixels‘).
Except for parts of the content which require two-dimensional layout for usage or meaning.
Note 1
320 CSS pixels is equivalent to a starting [viewport](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-viewport‘) width of 1280 CSS pixels wide at 400% zoom. For web content which is designed to scroll horizontally (e.g., with vertical text), 256 CSS pixels is equivalent to a starting viewport height of 1024 CSS pixels at 400% zoom.
Note 2
Examples of content which requires two-dimensional layout are images required for understanding (such as maps and diagrams), video, games, presentations, data tables (not individual cells), and interfaces where it is necessary to keep toolbars in view while manipulating content. It is acceptable to provide two-dimensional scrolling for such parts of the content.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.11 Non-text Contrast
content:
The visual [presentation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-presentation‘) of the following have a [contrast ratio](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-contrast-ratio‘) of at least 3:1 against adjacent color(s):
User Interface Components
Visual information required to identify [user interface components](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) and [states](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-states‘), except for inactive components or where the appearance of the component is determined by the [user agent](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘) and not modified by the author;
Graphical Objects
Parts of graphics required to understand the content, except when a particular presentation of graphics is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) to the information being conveyed.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.12 Text Spacing
content:
In content implemented using markup languages that support the following [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) [style properties](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-style-properties‘), no loss of content or functionality occurs by setting all of the following and by changing no other style property:
* Line height (line spacing) to at least 1.5 times the font size; * Spacing following paragraphs to at least 2 times the font size; * Letter spacing (tracking) to at least 0.12 times the font size; * Word spacing to at least 0.16 times the font size.
Exception: [Human languages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-human-language-s‘) and scripts that do not make use of one or more of these text style properties in written text can conform using only the properties that exist for that combination of language and script.
Note 1
Content is not required to use these text spacing values. The requirement is to ensure that when a user overrides the authored text spacing, content or functionality is not lost.
Note 2
Writing systems for some languages use different text spacing settings, such as paragraph start indent. Authors are encouraged to follow locally available guidance for improving readability and legibility of text in their writing system.

name: Success Criterion 1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus
understanding: [Understanding Content on Hover or Focus](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/content-on-hover-or-focus.html‘) | [How to Meet Content on Hover or Focus](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#content-on-hover-or-focus‘)
content:
Where receiving and then removing pointer hover or keyboard focus triggers additional content to become visible and then hidden, the following are true:
Dismissible
A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to dismiss the additional content without moving pointer hover or keyboard focus, unless the additional content communicates an [input error](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-input-error‘) or does not obscure or replace other content;
Hoverable
If pointer hover can trigger the additional content, then the pointer can be moved over the additional content without the additional content disappearing;
Persistent
The additional content remains visible until the hover or focus trigger is removed, the user dismisses it, or its information is no longer valid.
Exception: The visual presentation of the additional content is controlled by the [user agent](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘) and is not modified by the author.
Note 1
Examples of additional content controlled by the user agent include browser tooltips created through use of the HTML [`title` attribute](‘https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/dom.html#the-title-attribute‘) [[HTML](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#bib-html‘)].
Note 2
Custom tooltips, sub-menus, and other nonmodal popups that display on hover and focus are examples of additional content covered by this criterion.
Note 3
This criterion applies to content that appears in addition to the triggering component itself. Since hidden components that are made visible on keyboard focus (such as links used to skip to another part of a page) do not present additional content they are not covered by this criterion.

name: 2. Operable
content: User interface components and navigation must be operable.

name: Guideline 2.1 Keyboard Accessible
content:
[Understanding Keyboard Accessible](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/keyboard-accessible.html‘) | [How to Meet Keyboard Accessible](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#keyboard-accessible‘)
Make all functionality available from a keyboard.

name: Success Criterion 2.1.1 Keyboard
content:
All [functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-functionality‘) of the content is operable through a [keyboard interface](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-keyboard-interface‘) without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying function requires input that depends on the path of the users movement and not just the endpoints.
Note 1
This exception relates to the underlying function, not the input technique. For example, if using handwriting to enter text, the input technique (handwriting) requires path-dependent input but the underlying function (text input) does not.
Note 2
This does not forbid and should not discourage providing mouse input or other input methods in addition to keyboard operation.

name: Success Criterion 2.1.2 No Keyboard Trap
understanding: [Understanding No Keyboard Trap](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/no-keyboard-trap.html‘) | [How to Meet No Keyboard Trap](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#no-keyboard-trap‘)
content:
If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of the page using a [keyboard interface](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-keyboard-interface‘), then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface, and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab keys or other standard exit methods, the user is advised of the method for moving focus away.
Note
Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a users ability to use the whole page, all content on the web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See [Conformance Requirement 5: Non-Interference](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#cc5‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.1.3 Keyboard (No Exception)
content: All [functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-functionality‘) of the content is operable through a [keyboard interface](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-keyboard-interface‘) without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes.

name: Success Criterion 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts
understanding: [Understanding Character Key Shortcuts](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/character-key-shortcuts.html‘) | [How to Meet Character Key Shortcuts](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#character-key-shortcuts‘)
content:
If a [keyboard shortcut](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-keyboard-shortcuts‘) is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true:
Turn off
A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to turn the shortcut off;
Remap
A mechanism is available to remap the shortcut to include one or more non-printable keyboard keys (e.g., Ctrl, Alt);
Active only on focus
The keyboard shortcut for a [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) is only active when that component has focus.

name: Guideline 2.2 Enough Time
content:
[Understanding Enough Time](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/enough-time.html‘) | [How to Meet Enough Time](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#enough-time‘)
Provide users enough time to read and use content.

name: Success Criterion 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable
content:
For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true:
Turn off
The user is allowed to turn off the time limit before encountering it; or
Adjust
The user is allowed to adjust the time limit before encountering it over a wide range that is at least ten times the length of the default setting; or
Extend
The user is warned before time expires and given at least 20 seconds to extend the time limit with a simple action (for example, ‘press the space bar‘), and the user is allowed to extend the time limit at least ten times; or
Real-time Exception
The time limit is a required part of a [real-time event](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-real-time-events‘) (for example, an auction), and no alternative to the time limit is possible; or
Essential Exception
The time limit is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) and extending it would invalidate the activity; or
20 Hour Exception
The time limit is longer than 20 hours.
Note
This success criterion helps ensure that users can complete tasks without unexpected changes in content or context that are a result of a time limit. This success criterion should be considered in conjunction with [Success Criterion 3.2.1](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#on-focus‘), which puts limits on changes of content or context as a result of user action.

name: Success Criterion 2.2.2 Pause, Stop, Hide
understanding: [Understanding Pause, Stop, Hide](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/pause-stop-hide.html‘) | [How to Meet Pause, Stop, Hide](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#pause-stop-hide‘)
content:
For moving, [blinking](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-blinking‘), scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true:
Moving, blinking, scrolling
For any moving, blinking or scrolling information that (1) starts automatically, (2) lasts more than five seconds, and (3) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) for the user to [pause](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pause‘), stop, or hide it unless the movement, blinking, or scrolling is part of an activity where it is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘); and
Auto-updating
For any auto-updating information that (1) starts automatically and (2) is presented in parallel with other content, there is a mechanism for the user to pause, stop, or hide it or to control the frequency of the update unless the auto-updating is part of an activity where it is essential.
Note 1
For requirements related to flickering or flashing content, refer to [Guideline 2.3](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#seizures-and-physical-reactions‘).
Note 2
Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a users ability to use the whole page, all content on the web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See [Conformance Requirement 5: Non-Interference](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#cc5‘).
Note 3
Content that is updated periodically by software or that is streamed to the user agent is not required to preserve or present information that is generated or received between the initiation of the pause and resuming presentation, as this may not be technically possible, and in many situations could be misleading to do so.
Note 4
An animation that occurs as part of a preload phase or similar situation can be considered essential if interaction cannot occur during that phase for all users and if not indicating progress could confuse users or cause them to think that content was frozen or broken.

name: Success Criterion 2.2.3 No Timing
content: Timing is not an [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) part of the event or activity presented by the content, except for non-interactive [synchronized media](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-synchronized-media‘) and [real-time events](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-real-time-events‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.2.4 Interruptions
content: Interruptions can be postponed or suppressed by the user, except interruptions involving an [emergency](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-emergency‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.2.5 Re-authenticating
content: When an authenticated session expires, the user can continue the activity without loss of data after re-authenticating.

name: Success Criterion 2.2.6 Timeouts
content:
Users are warned of the duration of any [user inactivity](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-inactivity‘) that could cause data loss, unless the data is preserved for more than 20 hours when the user does not take any actions.
Note
Privacy regulations may require explicit user consent before user identification has been authenticated and before user data is preserved. In cases where the user is a minor, explicit consent may not be solicited in most jurisdictions, countries or regions. Consultation with privacy professionals and legal counsel is advised when considering data preservation as an approach to satisfy this success criterion.

name: Guideline 2.3 Seizures and Physical Reactions
content:
[Understanding Seizures and Physical Reactions](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/seizures-and-physical-reactions.html‘) | [How to Meet Seizures and Physical Reactions](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#seizures-and-physical-reactions‘)
Do not design content in a way that is known to cause seizures or physical reactions.

name: Success Criterion 2.3.1 Three Flashes or Below Threshold
understanding: [Understanding Three Flashes or Below Threshold](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/three-flashes-or-below-threshold.html‘) | [How to Meet Three Flashes or Below Threshold](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#three-flashes-or-below-threshold‘)
content:
[Web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the [flash](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-flashes‘) is below the [general flash and red flash thresholds](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-general-flash-and-red-flash-thresholds‘).
Note
Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a users ability to use the whole page, all content on the web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See [Conformance Requirement 5: Non-Interference](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#cc5‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.3.2 Three Flashes
content: [Web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) do not contain anything that [flashes](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-flashes‘) more than three times in any one second period.

name: Success Criterion 2.3.3 Animation from Interactions
understanding: [Understanding Animation from Interactions](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/animation-from-interactions.html‘) | [How to Meet Animation from Interactions](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#animation-from-interactions‘)
content: [Motion animation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-motion-animation‘) triggered by interaction can be disabled, unless the animation is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) to the functionality or the information being conveyed.

name: Guideline 2.4 Navigable
content:
[Understanding Navigable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/navigable.html‘) | [How to Meet Navigable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#navigable‘)
Provide ways to help users navigate, find content, and determine where they are.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.1 Bypass Blocks
content: A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple [web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.4.2 Page Titled
content: [Web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) have titles that describe topic or purpose.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.3 Focus Order
content: If a [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) can be [navigated sequentially](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-navigated-sequentially‘) and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.4 Link Purpose (In Context)
understanding: [Understanding Link Purpose (In Context)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/link-purpose-in-context.html‘) | [How to Meet Link Purpose (In Context)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#link-purpose-in-context‘)
content: The [purpose of each link](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-purpose-of-each-link‘) can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its [programmatically determined link context](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determined-link-context‘), except where the purpose of the link would be [ambiguous to users in general](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-ambiguous-to-users-in-general‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.4.5 Multiple Ways
content: More than one way is available to locate a [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) within a [set of web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-set-of-web-pages‘) except where the web page is the result of, or a step in, a [process](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-processes‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.4.6 Headings and Labels
understanding: [Understanding Headings and Labels](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/headings-and-labels.html‘) | [How to Meet Headings and Labels](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#headings-and-labels‘)
content: Headings and [labels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-labels‘) describe topic or purpose.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.7 Focus Visible
content: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard [focus indicator](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-focus-indicator‘) is visible.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.8 Location
content: Information about the users location within a [set of web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-set-of-web-pages‘) is available.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.9 Link Purpose (Link Only)
understanding: [Understanding Link Purpose (Link Only)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/link-purpose-link-only.html‘) | [How to Meet Link Purpose (Link Only)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#link-purpose-link-only‘)
content: A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to allow the [purpose of each link](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-purpose-of-each-link‘) to be identified from link text alone, except where the purpose of the link would be [ambiguous to users in general](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-ambiguous-to-users-in-general‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.4.10 Section Headings
content:
[Section](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-section‘) headings are used to organize the content.
Note 1
‘Heading‘ is used in its general sense and includes titles and other ways to add a heading to different types of content.
Note 2
This success criterion covers sections within writing, not [user interface components](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘). User interface components are covered under [Success Criterion 4.1.2](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#name-role-value‘).

name: Success Criterion 2.4.11 Focus Not Obscured (Minimum)
understanding: [Understanding Focus Not Obscured (Minimum)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/focus-not-obscured-minimum.html‘) | [How to Meet Focus Not Obscured (Minimum)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#focus-not-obscured-minimum‘)
content:
New
When a [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) receives keyboard focus, the component is not entirely hidden due to author-created content.
Note 1
Where content in a configurable interface can be repositioned by the user, then only the initial positions of user-movable content are considered for testing and conformance of this success criterion.
Note 2
Content opened by the _user_ may obscure the component receiving focus. If the user can reveal the focused component without advancing the keyboard focus, the component with focus is not considered visually hidden due to author-created content.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.12 Focus Not Obscured (Enhanced)
understanding: [Understanding Focus Not Obscured (Enhanced)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/focus-not-obscured-enhanced.html‘) | [How to Meet Focus Not Obscured (Enhanced)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#focus-not-obscured-enhanced‘)
content:
New
When a [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) receives keyboard focus, no part of the component is hidden by author-created content.

name: Success Criterion 2.4.13 Focus Appearance
content:
New
When the keyboard [focus indicator](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-focus-indicator‘) is visible, an area of the focus indicator meets all the following:
* is at least as large as the area of a 2 [CSS pixel](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-css-pixels‘) thick [perimeter](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-perimeter‘) of the unfocused component or sub-component, and * has a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 between the same pixels in the focused and unfocused states.
Exceptions:
* The focus indicator is determined by the [user agent](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘) and cannot be adjusted by the author, or * The focus indicator and the indicators background color are not modified by the author.
Note 1
What is perceived as the user interface component or sub-component (to determine the perimeter) depends on its visual [presentation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-presentation‘). The visual presentation includes the components visible [content](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-content‘), border, and component-specific background. It does not include shadow and glow effects outside the components content, background, or border.
Note 2
Examples of sub-components that may receive a focus indicator are menu items in an opened drop-down menu, or focusable cells in a grid.
Note 3
Contrast calculations can be based on colors defined within the [technology](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-technologies‘) (such as HTML, CSS, and SVG). Pixels modified by user agent resolution enhancements and anti-aliasing can be ignored.

name: Guideline 2.5 Input Modalities
content:
[Understanding Input Modalities](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/input-modalities.html‘) | [How to Meet Input Modalities](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#input-modalities‘)
Make it easier for users to operate functionality through various inputs beyond keyboard.

name: Success Criterion 2.5.1 Pointer Gestures
content:
All [functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-functionality‘) that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a [single pointer](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-single-pointer‘) without a path-based gesture, unless a multipoint or path-based gesture is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘).
Note
This requirement applies to web content that interprets pointer actions (i.e., this does not apply to actions that are required to operate the user agent or assistive technology).

name: Success Criterion 2.5.2 Pointer Cancellation
content:
For [functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-functionality‘) that can be operated using a [single pointer](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-single-pointer‘), at least one of the following is true:
No Down-Event
The [down-event](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-down-event‘) of the pointer is not used to execute any part of the function;
Abort or Undo
Completion of the function is on the [up-event](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-up-event‘), and a [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to abort the function before completion or to undo the function after completion;
Up Reversal
The up-event reverses any outcome of the preceding down-event;
Essential
Completing the function on the down-event is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘).
Note 1
Functions that emulate a keyboard or numeric keypad key press are considered essential.
Note 2
This requirement applies to web content that interprets pointer actions (i.e., this does not apply to actions that are required to operate the user agent or assistive technology).

name: Success Criterion 2.5.3 Label in Name
understanding: [Understanding Label in Name](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/label-in-name.html‘) | [How to Meet Label in Name](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#label-in-name‘)
content:
For [user interface components](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) with [labels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-labels‘) that include [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘) or [images of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-images-of-text‘), the [name](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-name‘) contains the text that is presented visually.
Note
A best practice is to have the text of the label at the start of the name.

name: Success Criterion 2.5.4 Motion Actuation
content:
[Functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-functionality‘) that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by [user interface components](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) and responding to the motion can be disabled to prevent accidental actuation, except when:
Supported Interface
The motion is used to operate functionality through an [accessibility supported](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-accessibility-supported‘) interface;
Essential
The motion is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) for the function and doing so would invalidate the activity.

name: Success Criterion 2.5.5 Target Size (Enhanced)
understanding: [Understanding Target Size (Enhanced)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/target-size-enhanced.html‘) | [How to Meet Target Size (Enhanced)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#target-size-enhanced‘)
content:
The size of the [target](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-targets‘) for [pointer inputs](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pointer-inputs‘) is at least 44 by 44 [CSS pixels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-css-pixels‘) except when:
Equivalent
The target is available through an equivalent link or control on the same page that is at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels;
Inline
The target is in a sentence or [block of text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-blocks-of-text‘);
User Agent Control
The size of the target is determined by the [user agent](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘) and is not modified by the author;
Essential
A particular [presentation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-presentation‘) of the target is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) to the information being conveyed.

name: Success Criterion 2.5.6 Concurrent Input Mechanisms
understanding: [Understanding Concurrent Input Mechanisms](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/concurrent-input-mechanisms.html‘) | [How to Meet Concurrent Input Mechanisms](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#concurrent-input-mechanisms‘)
content: Web content does not restrict use of input modalities available on a platform except where the restriction is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘), required to ensure the security of the content, or required to respect user settings.

name: Success Criterion 2.5.7 Dragging Movements
content:
New
All [functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-functionality‘) that uses a [dragging movement](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-dragging-movements‘) for operation can be achieved by a [single pointer](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-single-pointer‘) without dragging, unless dragging is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) or the functionality is determined by the [user agent](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘) and not modified by the author.
Note
This requirement applies to web content that interprets pointer actions (i.e., this does not apply to actions that are required to operate the user agent or assistive technology).

name: Success Criterion 2.5.8 Target Size (Minimum)
understanding: [Understanding Target Size (Minimum)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/target-size-minimum.html‘) | [How to Meet Target Size (Minimum)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#target-size-minimum‘)
content:
New
The size of the [target](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-targets‘) for [pointer inputs](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-pointer-inputs‘) is at least 24 by 24 [CSS pixels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-css-pixels‘), except when:
Spacing
Undersized targets (those less than 24 by 24 CSS pixels) are positioned so that if a 24 CSS pixel diameter circle is centered on the [bounding box](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-bounding-boxes‘) of each, the circles do not intersect another target or the circle for another undersized target;
Equivalent
The function can be achieved through a different control on the same page that meets this criterion;
Inline
The target is in a sentence or its size is otherwise constrained by the line-height of non-target text;
User Agent Control
The size of the target is determined by the [user agent](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘) and is not modified by the author;
Essential
A particular [presentation](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-presentation‘) of the target is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘) or is legally required for the information being conveyed.
Note 1
Targets that allow for values to be selected spatially based on position within the target are considered one target for the purpose of the success criterion. Examples include sliders, color pickers displaying a gradient of colors, or editable areas where you position the cursor.
Note 2
For inline targets the line-height should be interpreted as perpendicular to the flow of text. For example, in a language displayed vertically, the line-height would be horizontal.

name: 3. Understandable
content: Information and the operation of the user interface must be understandable.

name: Guideline 3.1 Readable
content:
[Understanding Readable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/readable.html‘) | [How to Meet Readable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#readable‘)
Make text content readable and understandable.

name: Success Criterion 3.1.1 Language of Page
understanding: [Understanding Language of Page](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/language-of-page.html‘) | [How to Meet Language of Page](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#language-of-page‘)
content: The default [human language](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-human-language-s‘) of each [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘).

name: Success Criterion 3.1.2 Language of Parts
understanding: [Understanding Language of Parts](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/language-of-parts.html‘) | [How to Meet Language of Parts](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#language-of-parts‘)
content: The [human language](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-human-language-s‘) of each passage or phrase in the content can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘) except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding [text](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-text‘).

name: Success Criterion 3.1.3 Unusual Words
content: A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available for identifying specific definitions of words or phrases [used in an unusual or restricted way](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-used-in-an-unusual-or-restricted-way‘), including [idioms](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-idioms‘) and [jargon](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-jargon‘).

name: Success Criterion 3.1.4 Abbreviations
content: A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) for identifying the expanded form or meaning of [abbreviations](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-abbreviations‘) is available.

name: Success Criterion 3.1.5 Reading Level
content: When text requires reading ability more advanced than the [lower secondary education level](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-lower-secondary-education-level‘) after removal of proper names and titles, [supplemental content](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-supplementary-content‘), or a version that does not require reading ability more advanced than the lower secondary education level, is available.

name: Success Criterion 3.1.6 Pronunciation
content: A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available for identifying specific pronunciation of words where meaning of the words, in context, is ambiguous without knowing the pronunciation.

name: Guideline 3.2 Predictable
content:
[Understanding Predictable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/predictable.html‘) | [How to Meet Predictable](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#predictable‘)
Make web pages appear and operate in predictable ways.

name: Success Criterion 3.2.1 On Focus
content: When any [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) receives focus, it does not initiate a [change of context](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-change-of-context‘).

name: Success Criterion 3.2.2 On Input
content: Changing the setting of any [user interface component](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) does not automatically cause a [change of context](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-change-of-context‘) unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component.

name: Success Criterion 3.2.3 Consistent Navigation
content: Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple [web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) within a [set of web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-set-of-web-pages‘) occur in the [same relative order](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-same-relative-order‘) each time they are repeated, unless a change is initiated by the user.

name: Success Criterion 3.2.4 Consistent Identification
content: Components that have the [same functionality](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-same-functionality‘) within a [set of web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-set-of-web-pages‘) are identified consistently.

name: Success Criterion 3.2.5 Change on Request
understanding: [Understanding Change on Request](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/change-on-request.html‘) | [How to Meet Change on Request](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#change-on-request‘)
content: [Changes of context](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-change-of-context‘) are initiated only by user request or a [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to turn off such changes.

name: Success Criterion 3.2.6 Consistent Help
content:
New
If a [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) contains any of the following help [mechanisms](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘), and those mechanisms are repeated on multiple web pages within a [set of web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-set-of-web-pages‘), they occur in the same order relative to other page content, unless a change is initiated by the user:
* Human contact details; * Human contact mechanism; * Self-help option; * A fully automated contact mechanism.
Note 1
Help mechanisms may be provided directly on the page, or may be provided via a direct link to a different page containing the information.
Note 2
For this success criterion, ‘the same order relative to other page content‘ can be thought of as how the content is ordered when the page is serialized. The visual position of a help mechanism is likely to be consistent across pages for the same page variation (e.g., CSS break-point). The user can initiate a change, such as changing the pages zoom or orientation, which may trigger a different page variation. This criterion is concerned with relative order across pages displayed in the same page variation (e.g., same zoom level and orientation).

name: Guideline 3.3 Input Assistance
content:
[Understanding Input Assistance](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/input-assistance.html‘) | [How to Meet Input Assistance](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#input-assistance‘)
Help users avoid and correct mistakes.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.1 Error Identification
content: If an [input error](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-input-error‘) is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
understanding: [Understanding Labels or Instructions](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/labels-or-instructions.html‘) | [How to Meet Labels or Instructions](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#labels-or-instructions‘)
content: [Labels](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-labels‘) or instructions are provided when content requires user input.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.3 Error Suggestion
content: If an [input error](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-input-error‘) is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the content.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.4 Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data)
understanding: [Understanding Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/error-prevention-legal-financial-data.html‘) | [How to Meet Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#error-prevention-legal-financial-data‘)
content:
For [web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) that cause [legal commitments](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-legal-commitments‘) or financial transactions for the user to occur, that modify or delete [user-controllable](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-controllable‘) data in data storage systems, or that submit user test responses, at least one of the following is true:
Reversible
Submissions are reversible.
Checked
Data entered by the user is checked for [input errors](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-input-error‘) and the user is provided an opportunity to correct them.
Confirmed
A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available for reviewing, confirming, and correcting information before finalizing the submission.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.5 Help
content: [Context-sensitive help](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-context-sensitive-help‘) is available.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.6 Error Prevention (All)
understanding: [Understanding Error Prevention (All)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/error-prevention-all.html‘) | [How to Meet Error Prevention (All)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#error-prevention-all‘)
content:
For [web pages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) that require the user to submit information, at least one of the following is true:
Reversible
Submissions are reversible.
Checked
Data entered by the user is checked for [input errors](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-input-error‘) and the user is provided an opportunity to correct them.
Confirmed
A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available for reviewing, confirming, and correcting information before finalizing the submission.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.7 Redundant Entry
content:
New
Information previously entered by or provided to the user that is required to be entered again in the same [process](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-processes‘) is either:
* auto-populated, or * available for the user to select.
Except when:
* re-entering the information is [essential](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-essential‘), * the information is required to ensure the security of the content, or * previously entered information is no longer valid.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.8 Accessible Authentication (Minimum)
understanding: [Understanding Accessible Authentication (Minimum)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/accessible-authentication-minimum.html‘) | [How to Meet Accessible Authentication (Minimum)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#accessible-authentication-minimum‘)
content:
New
A [cognitive function test](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-cognitive-function-test‘) (such as remembering a password or solving a puzzle) is not required for any step in an authentication [process](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-processes‘) unless that step provides at least one of the following:
Alternative
Another authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test.
Mechanism
A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to assist the user in completing the cognitive function test.
Object Recognition
The cognitive function test is to recognize objects.
Personal Content
The cognitive function test is to identify [non-text content](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-non-text-content‘) the user provided to the website.
Note 1
‘Object recognition‘ and ‘Personal content‘ may be represented by images, video, or audio.
Note 2
Examples of mechanisms that satisfy this criterion include:
* support for password entry by password managers to reduce memory need, and * copy and paste to reduce the cognitive burden of re-typing.

name: Success Criterion 3.3.9 Accessible Authentication (Enhanced)
understanding: [Understanding Accessible Authentication (Enhanced)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/accessible-authentication-enhanced.html‘) | [How to Meet Accessible Authentication (Enhanced)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#accessible-authentication-enhanced‘)
content:
New
A [cognitive function test](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-cognitive-function-test‘) (such as remembering a password or solving a puzzle) is not required for any step in an authentication [process](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-processes‘) unless that step provides at least one of the following:
Alternative
Another authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test.
Mechanism
A [mechanism](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-mechanism‘) is available to assist the user in completing the cognitive function test.

name: 4. Robust
content: Content must be robust enough that it can be interpreted by a wide variety of user agents, including assistive technologies.

name: Guideline 4.1 Compatible
content:
[Understanding Compatible](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/compatible.html‘) | [How to Meet Compatible](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#compatible‘)
Maximize compatibility with current and future user agents, including assistive technologies.

name: Success Criterion 4.1.1 Parsing (Obsolete and removed)
content:
[Understanding Parsing (Obsolete and removed)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/parsing.html‘) | [How to Meet Parsing (Obsolete and removed)](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#parsing‘)
Note
This criterion was originally adopted to address problems that assistive technology had directly parsing HTML. Assistive technology no longer has any need to directly parse HTML. Consequently, these problems either no longer exist or are addressed by other criteria. This criterion no longer has utility and is removed.

name: Success Criterion 4.1.2 Name, Role, Value
understanding: [Understanding Name, Role, Value](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/name-role-value.html‘) | [How to Meet Name, Role, Value](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/quickref/#name-role-value‘)
content:
For all [user interface components](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-interface-components‘) (including but not limited to: form elements, links and components generated by scripts), the [name](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-name‘) and [role](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-role‘) can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘); [states](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-states‘), properties, and values that can be set by the user can be [programmatically set](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-set‘); and notification of changes to these items is available to [user agents](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-user-agents‘), including [assistive technologies](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-assistive-technologies‘).
Note
This success criterion is primarily for web authors who develop or script their own user interface components. For example, standard HTML controls already meet this success criterion when used according to specification.

name: Success Criterion 4.1.3 Status Messages
content: In content implemented using markup languages, [status messages](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-status-messages‘) can be [programmatically determined](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-programmatically-determinable‘) through [role](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-role‘) or properties such that they can be presented to the user by [assistive technologies](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-assistive-technologies‘) without receiving focus.

name: 5. Conformance
content: This section lists requirements for [conformance](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-conform‘) to WCAG 2.2. It also gives information about how to make conformance claims, which are optional. Finally, it describes what it means to be [accessibility supported](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-accessibility-supported‘), since only accessibility-supported ways of using technologies can be [relied upon](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-relied-upon‘) for conformance. [Understanding Conformance](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/conformance‘) includes further explanation of the accessibility-supported concept.

name: 5.1 Interpreting Normative Requirements
content:
The main content of WCAG 2.2 is [normative](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-normative‘) and defines requirements that impact conformance claims. Introductory material, appendices, sections marked as ‘non-normative‘, diagrams, examples, and notes are [informative](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-informative‘) (non-normative). Non-normative material provides advisory information to help interpret the guidelines but does not create requirements that impact a conformance claim.
The key words _MAY_, _MUST_, _MUST NOT_, _NOT RECOMMENDED_, _RECOMMENDED_, _SHOULD_, and _SHOULD NOT_ are to be interpreted as described in [[RFC2119](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#bib-rfc2119‘)].

name: 5.2 Conformance Requirements
content: In order for a web page to conform to WCAG 2.2, all of the following conformance requirements must be satisfied:

name: 5.2.1 Conformance Level
content:
One of the following levels of conformance is met in full.
* For Level A conformance (the minimum level of conformance), the [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) [satisfies](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-satisfies‘) all the Level A success criteria, or a [conforming alternate version](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-conforming-alternate-versions‘) is provided. * For Level AA conformance, the web page satisfies all the Level A and Level AA success criteria, or a Level AA conforming alternate version is provided. * For Level AAA conformance, the web page satisfies all the Level A, Level AA and Level AAA success criteria, or a Level AAA conforming alternate version is provided.
Note 1
Although conformance can only be achieved at the stated levels, authors are encouraged to report (in their claim) any progress toward meeting success criteria from all levels beyond the achieved level of conformance.
Note 2
It is not recommended that Level AAA conformance be required as a general policy for entire sites because it is not possible to satisfy all Level AAA success criteria for some content.

name: 5.2.2 Full pages
content:
[Conformance](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-conform‘) (and conformance level) is for full [web page(s)](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) only, and cannot be achieved if part of a web page is excluded.
Note 1
For the purpose of determining conformance, alternatives to part of a pages content are considered part of the page when the alternatives can be obtained directly from the page, e.g., a long description or an alternative presentation of a video.
Note 2
Authors of web pages that cannot conform due to content outside of the authors control may consider a [Statement of Partial Conformance](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#conformance-partial‘).
Note 3
A full page includes each variation of the page that is automatically presented by the page for various screen sizes (e.g. variations in a responsive web page). Each of these variations needs to conform (or needs to have a conforming alternate version) in order for the entire page to conform.

name: 5.2.3 Complete processes
content:
When a [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) is one of a series of web pages presenting a [process](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-processes‘) (i.e., a sequence of steps that need to be completed in order to accomplish an activity), all web pages in the process conform at the specified level or better. (Conformance is not possible at a particular level if any page in the process does not conform at that level or better.)
Example
An online store has a series of pages that are used to select and purchase products. All pages in the series from start to finish (checkout) conform in order for any page that is part of the process to conform.

name: 5.2.4 Only Accessibility-Supported Ways of Using Technologies
content: Only [accessibility-supported](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-accessibility-supported‘) ways of using [technologies](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-technologies‘) are [relied upon](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-relied-upon‘) to satisfy the success criteria. Any information or functionality that is provided in a way that is not accessibility supported is also available in a way that is accessibility supported. (See [Understanding accessibility support](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/conformance#accessibility-support‘).)

name: 5.2.5 Non-Interference
content:
If [technologies](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-technologies‘) are used in a way that is not [accessibility supported](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-accessibility-supported‘), or if they are used in a non-conforming way, then they do not block the ability of users to access the rest of the page. In addition, the [web page](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-web-page-s‘) as a whole continues to meet the conformance requirements under each of the following conditions:
1. when any technology that is not [relied upon](‘https://www.w3.org/TR/2024/REC-WCAG22-20241212/#dfn-relied-upon‘) is turned on in a user agent, 2. when any technology that is not relied upon is turned off in a user agent, and 3. when any technology that is not relied upon is not supported by a user agent
In addition, the following success criteria apply to all content on the page, including content that is not otherwise relied upon to meet conformance, because failure to meet them could interfere with any use of the page:
* **1.4.2 - Audio Control**, * **2.1.2 - No Keyboard Trap**, * **2.3.1 - Three Flashes or Below Threshold**, and * **2.2.2 - Pause, Stop, Hide**.
Note
If a page cannot conform (for example, a conformance test page or an example page), it cannot be included in the scope of conformance or in a conformance claim.
For more information, including examples, see [Understanding Conformance Requirements](‘https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/conformance#conformance-requirements‘).

name: 5.3 Conformance Claims (Optional)
